Subject: Slavery. & ff ' yU3- (4 I have the honour to report the following incident. 2. A certain slave, one ’Abdullah bin Sai’d,a Sa’udi subject - born in Najd, came to Bahrain from Dammam in Hasa about 3 months ago and applied to Colonel Loch for manumis sion. Since ’Abdullah was a foreign subject Colonel Loch referred the case to me, recommending manumission, which I Airhhorised. 3 # 1 Abdullah was accordingly manumitted, but towards the end of last month was foolish enough to pay a visit to Hasa as one of the crew of a dhow plying to Lakhbar (close to Dammam)• He landed to collect wood, and was forcibly seized in the presence of the local Mudir by relatives of his former master, one Saleh bin Ahmed Dosiri of the Dawasir tribe, the dhow returning to Bahrain without him. 4. Colonel Loch reported this occurrence, but informed me shortly afterwards that ’Abdullah had been released and had returned to Bahrain. The cause of ’Abdullah’s release was apparently that some one in Bahrain had written to the Dawasir in Dammam that a complaint had been made, and the Dawasir feared reprisals: they have property in, and frequently visit, Bahrain.- 2 - 5. The matter has thus ended satisfactorily, but in the event of similar cases arising in the future, and the manumitted slave not being returned, it may be worth while to consider what action - if any - we can take. Under Article 7 of the Treaty of Jedda Ibn Saud promised to co-operate by all means at his disposal with His Majesty’s Government in the suppression of the Slave Trade, and in his letter of May 19th Sir Gilbert Clayton informed Ibn Saud that His Majesty’s Government could not renounce the right of manumission of slaves by their Consular Officers: presumably from the context those Officers in Saudi Arabia. 6. Whether in order to obtain the release of a manumitted slave we couldjbase our representation on Article 7 of the Jedda Treaty, or whether we should adopt the attitude that if a Saudi manumitted slave is foolish enough to return to Saudi Arabia he should be left to take the consequences, are questions which His Majesty’s Government may like to consider and give a ruling on. I am sending copies of this letter to the Government of India, His Majesty’s Minister at Jedda and the Political Agent at Bahrain. I have the honour to be. Sir, Your most obedient humble servant, c.- Lieut .-Colonel. Political Resident in the Persian Gulf.

titleInfo.title: Coll 34/8 'Slavery and Slave Trade: Persian Gulf manumissions: Liability of manumitted Saudi subjects to be reduced to slaves again on return to Saudi Arabia'

physicalDescription.extent: The file is arranged in chronological order from the back to the front.

Foliation: the foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 7; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio.

mods.abstract: Correspondence between officials at the India Office and Foreign Office concerning what action might be taken if manumitted slaves from Saudi Arabia are detained upon their return to their country. The question is discussed following a report of such a case by Lieutenant-Colonel Trenchard Craven William Fowle, Political Resident in the Persian Gulf (folios 6-7).
